White House confirmed US President Trump will meet with Mexico President Pena Nieto, while there were also comments from Mexican NAFTA negotiator who noted 6 to 10 chapters are ready to close and that there is still a lot of work to do on autos. (Newswires)

Data Recap
US PPI Final Demand MM (Jan) 0.4% vs. Exp. 0.4% (Prev. -0.1%). (Newswires)
US PPI Final Demand YY (Jan) 2.7% vs. Exp. 2.5% (Prev. 2.6%)
US Manufacturing Output MM (Jan) 0.0% vs. Exp. 0.3% (Prev. 0.1%)
US Industrial Production MM (Jan) -0.1% vs. Exp. 0.2% (Prev. 0.9%, Rev. 0.4%)
US NY Fed Manufacturing (Feb) 13.1 vs. Exp. 17.50 (Prev. 17.70)
 


UK/EUROPE


Norwegian Central Bank Governor Olsen said may hike interest rates this year and that the NOK exchange rate puts limits on how far rates can deviate from other countries. (Newswires)


FX

FOREX: DXY trades 0.65% lower heading into APAC trade. The USD slide continues, with the DXY sliding for the fourth day this week; if it prints red tomorrow, the dollar index will have seen a daily decline every day this week. There wasn’t any fresh reason for the declines, with the analyst community content to use the protectionism/stagflation/global growth-allowing-other-FX-to-play-catch-up narrative. The index itself is now flirting with the 88.50 mark, which some technical analysts have suggested is a triple bottom near the 61.8% retracement level of the 2014 low to 2017 high. The result was EUR jumped above 1.25 again – which will likely irritate officials at ECB HQ, JPY on the cusp of breaching 106.00 (there was brief weakness for the yen vs the USD after news that academic Professor Wakatabe was in the frame for the BOJ deputy governor role. Though weakness was fleeting – an announcement on BOJ positions may come overnight, according to some reports), and allowing GBP to sit at 1.41. EMFX naturally took advantage of the firmer risk tone, though the BRL was lower vs the USD after inflation data. 

 

COMMODITIES

CRUDE: WTI futures settle 74 cents higher at USD 61.34 per barrel; Brent futures settle 3 cents lower at USD 64.33 per barrel. A weaker dollar was being cited as the reason crude pared back losses on Thursday (WTI LOD was around $59.65, Brent LOD was around $63.10). Traders continued to cite the Russia/Saudi comments from yesterday (where Saudi said it will trim production next month) as well as this week’s inventory data, which showed smaller than expected builds for headline crude. Traders also noted that Brent’s premium to WTI was narrowing to six-month lows.

UAE Energy Minister said oil producers led by Saudi Arabia and Russia aim to draft an agreement on long-term alliance by the year-end. (Newswires)

Venezuela's President Maduro said Venezuelan oil production is up 250k BPD since start of the year. (Newswires)

White House Legislative Director Short said there is no support for a gas tax hike in Congress. (Newswires)


GEOPOLITICAL

South Korean President Moon could visit North Korea if the N.Korean stance changes, according to reports. (Newswires)


MARKET RECAP

The emini extended gains for a fifth day, continuing to pare-back losses incurred after the volatility-induced slide. The March contract rose to highs above 2725, after breaking through the 2720 resistance level (now turned support). Grinding out gains is proving tough work, and the contract remains around 5% off highs near 2785. Traders continued to cite the healthy landscape of corporate America (solid earnings, fiscal reform boost, etc), and decent prospects for global growth as the driver. In terms of sectors, tech and industrials were leading; Apple was higher after Berkshire Hathaway made the company its top investment, while Cisco’s results released on Wednesday were received well. Energy was the laggard, after crude softness in early trade. The VIX, meanwhile remains under the 20 handle. SPX +1.21% at 2731, DJI +1.23% at 25200, NDX +1.8% at 6795.

Top performers: Utilities +1.75%, Tech +1.72%, Industrials +1.23%.
Bottom performers: Energy -0.50%, Financials +0.47%, Cons Cyclicals +0.52%.

The surge higher in yields paused on Thursday, with buyers emerging as 10-year yields rose above 2.90% (2.94% was the HOD). Today’s data slate (PPI, industrial production, Philly Fed, weekly jobless claims) had little influence on price action, with the narrative still fixed on inflationary pressures following the January payrolls data which signalled wages were firming, and January’s CPI data released this week, that surprised to the upside; yesterday’s retail sales missed was being explained away as a blip following retail inventories being drawn down strongly, leaving retailers with little need to slash prices in January sales, perhaps explaining the weakness in the January retail sales data. The US Treasury auctioned new 30-year tips, tailing by 1.4bps, though indirect participation was encouraging. The US Treasury announced it will next week auction $28bln in 2s, $35bln in 5s, and $29bln in 7s, as well as $15bln of 2y FRNs. At settlement, The Treasuries were little changed on the day, with most of the action focussed in the long end, where yields fell by just shy of 3bps. T-Note Futures settle 4 ticks higher at 120-14+.

BoC’s Deputy Governor Schembri says if cyclical forces which boost the economy out of slowdown are powerful then policy might have to be more aggressive
content:
- Higher debt levels, decline in rates, decreasing economic trends may challenge policy framework
- Inflation and inflationary expectations remain firmly anchored
- BOC's 1-3% inflation band reflects normal deviations in CPI. Temporary factors mean it is impossible to hit 2.00% target on a consistent basis. Adds 2.00% target is symmetric
- BoC sees a neutral rate approximately in the 2.5% to 3.5% range
- BoC taking cautious approach to normalising interest rates, does not mean rates will be low forever but they keeping a firm eye on data

subject: FX Daily Wrap: Dollar off the floor, but still on its knees
content: Some scant respite for the Greenback, but only vs a select few major counterparts, like the Eur that continues to run into chart resistance just above 1.2500 and the 1.2537 year to date peak. Bids reportedly around 106.30 in Usd/Jpy are propping that pair, but offers at 106.80 and 107.00 are capping rebounds and a sub-106.50 looks ominous and technically bearish. Usd/Chf is hovering just above 0.9200, while Cable has built on earlier gains above 1.4000 and almost reached the next big figure having surpassed the high set on BoE ‘super’ Thursday last week – next upside target 1.4150 (5th February peak). Nzd/Usd back below 0.7400 and Aud/Usd just above 0.7900, with latter now looking for further independent direction from RBA’s Lowe, while the Loonie is the G10 laggard after mixed Canadian data (ADP up, but CREA home sales down sharply) and also awaiting some CB impetus from BoC’s Schembri. The DXY has bounced off worst levels as a result, but only towards the middle of a broad 89.000-88.500 range as the US fiscal outlook and twin deficits continue to sour sentiment.

content: Core debt retesting session highs in wake of the US production and output misses predictably, but perhaps peculiarly didn’t challenge the intraday lows earlier when PPI beat consensus to confirm the rise in price pressures seen via CPI on Wednesday. It looks like the more pronounced flattening along the US Treasury curve is lending EU bonds some support as 10 and 30 year T-note and long bond futures both rebound above parity. Bunds now 22 ticks adrift vs -56 ticks at one stage and Gilts 35 ticks underwater vs -69 ticks at worst.

DAILY US OPENING NEWS: European equities firmer across the board. SMI lags as Nestle earnings disappoint
content:
15th December 2017

  • European equities firmer across the board. SMI lags as Nestle earnings disappoint
  • USD softer once again with USD/JPY below 106.50. ZAR remains supported with Ramaphosa now appointed as President
  • Looking ahead, highlights include US weekly jobs, Philly Fed, PPI, IP and a slew of speakers

ASIA

Asian stocks traded higher as the region received a tailwind from US where all major indices finished with firm gains and the DJIA posted its best 4-day performance in almost a decade. ASX 200 (+1.2%) was positive with its biggest movers dictated by earnings releases and as commodity names were underpinned by strength in the complex. Elsewhere, Nikkei 225 (+1.5%) advanced and managed to overlook a firmer JPY and slump in machine orders, while Hang Seng (+1.6%) closed the session as the outperformer in a holiday-shortened session, before it joined its mainland counterparts for Lunar New Year celebrations. Finally, 10yr JGBs were relatively flat with early mild pressure seen amid the uptick in riskier assets, although this was later counterbalanced amid the BoJ’s presence in the market for 1yr-10yr JGBs totalling over JPY 1tln.

Japanese government may provide a list of nominees for BoJ Governor and Deputy Governors on Friday. (Newswires)

Japanese Machinery Orders MM (Dec) -11.9% vs. Exp. -2.0% (Prev. 5.7%). (Newswires)

Japanese Machinery Orders YY (Dec) -5.0% vs. Exp. 1.8% (Prev. 4.1%)

Australian Employment Change (Jan) 16.0k vs. Exp. 15.0k (Prev. 34.7k, Rev. 33.5k). (Newswires)

Australian Unemployment Rate (Jan) 5.5% vs. Exp. 5.5% (Prev. 5.5%, Rev. 5.6%)

Australian Full Time Employment Change (Jan) -49.8k (Prev. 15.1k, Rev. 12.7k)

Australian Part-Time Employment Change (Jan) 65.9k (Prev. 19.5k)

EU/UK

UK PM May is reportedly facing a crisis related to the Brexit border deal, after Northern Ireland power sharing discussions were said to have collapsed. (Telegraph)

The EU will demand the right to raid financial services firms in Britain after Brexit and hand its regulators sweeping new powers, as Brussels moves to shackle the City of London with red tape after the UK leaves the bloc. (Telegraph)

EU diplomats have removed a so-called "punishment clause" from a draft text of the arrangement for the Brexit transition period, the BBC understands. (BBC) However, it was later reported that the EU denied this was the case.

EQUITIES

European bourses trade higher across the board (Eurostoxx 50 +0.6%) in a continuation of the sentiment seen yesterday on Wall Street and overnight in Asia-Pac trade. On a sector basis, consumer staples underperform following lacklustre earnings from Swiss-titan Nestle (-2.2%), with the index heavyweight subsequently leading the SMI to lag its peers in the region. Elsewhere, South African exposed Old Mutual (+3.8%) and Anglo American (+3.0%) lead the FTSE 100 as South Africa now eyes life-after Zuma with Ramaphosa now appointed as Preisdent. Miners occupy a bulk of the other outperformers in the UK amid movements in the commodity complex with Antofagasta (+2.9%) also lifted after winning approval for a USD 1.1bln revamp of its Los Pelambres copper mine. Elsewhere, Standard Life (-4.9%) sits at the bottom of the FSTE 100 after Scottish Widows and Lloyds sent notices to co. to terminate investment management relations. Finally, earnings dominate the state of play in the CAC with Airbus (+9.3%), Schneider Electric (+3.6%) and CapGemini (+2.5%) all lifted by encouraging earnings.

FX

Japan’s Finance Minister Aso has seemingly given the green light for Jpy bulls to charge on, and 106.00 vs the Usd is now within striking distance given little in the way of technical support until 105.85 vs the latest 106.20 low. Moreover, all other G10 rivals are eyeing recent peaks vs the Greenback with Cable just eclipsing the 1.4067 level posted after the BoE’s hawkish policy guidance shift on February 8th, while Eur/Usd almost challenged Fib resistance at 1.2518 ahead of the 1.2537 year to date high before slipping back below 1.2500. Usd/Chf is toppy around the bottom of a 0.9300-0.9230 range, while Nzd/Usd has rebounded above the 0.7400 handle and Aud/Usd is over 0.7950 despite mixed jobs data overnight and ahead of RBA Governor Lowe orates later today. Usd/Cad relatively steady albeit sharply down from Wednesday’s post-US CPI data spike highs and sub-1.2500 amidst ongoing NAFTA uncertainty and awaiting a speech from BoC Deputy Governor Schembri. All this leaves the Dollar Index below 89.00 again and vulnerable against a deeper set-back towards 2018 lows under 88.50, especially as the Usd continues to suffer broader losses with the likes of Usd/Zar sliding towards 11.6400 in wake of the resignation of Zuma as SA President with immediate effect.

ANC party are to nominate Cyril Ramaphosa as President, according to ANC; as expected. (Newswires)

FIXED INCOME

UK fixed was already probing new Liffe lows in the run up to the DMO auction but succumbed to a bit more downside pressure after the results revealed a lengthy 19 tick price or 0.7 bp yield tail, even with the lofty 1.914% average cost of funding. The 10 year future inched close to the next round number at 120.13 (-69 ticks vs the previous close), and Bunds appear to have fallen in sympathy to a fresh Eurex base at 157.43 (-55 ticks). In truth, much like the Usd core bonds are in a downward spiral and corresponding yields are inclining in bear-flattening mode regardless. USTs are only a few ticks off worst levels, albeit with the long bond future back in positive terrain. In yield terms, the benchmark US 10 year maturity is just easing back from a new high in the recent/current cycle around 2.93% and 3% seems that natural assumption from here, with 3.25% in mind for 30 year cash for the same psychological if not technical rationale.

COMMODITIES

In the commodities complex, WTI and Brent crude futures trade in close proximity to recent highs seen in the wake of yesterday’s smaller than expected build in the DoEs and comments from Saudi with prices also supported by the broad softness in the USD. In metals, gold prices have also benefitted from the softer USD, although gains are likely capped by the broad-based risk sentiment in the market. Elsewhere, copper prices have hit their highest level in 10 days amid this morning’s risk environment, while price action was relatively limited during Asia-Pac trade given the closure of the Shanghai Futures Exchange for the Lunar New Year holiday.

UK DEBT AND STIR FUTURES: catch-up losses off the Liffe open, as expected
content: No surprise to see Gilts correct lower in wake of extended declines for core bond counterparts following yesterday’s above forecast US CPI (not to mention a similar UK inflation beat on Tuesday), as the 10 year benchmark hit a 120.39 base (-43 ticks on the day) before consolidating and recovering a bit to a 120.57 high alongside Bunds (latter testing near term resistance around 157.75 having just topped out at 157.78). The Short Sterling strip is also attempting to draw a line in the sand with 3 month contracts now broadly flat from 1-2 ticks below par at one stage. Back to Gilts, rebounds may be capped amidst the overall bear trend in debt markets ahead of DMO issuance in the form of Gbp2.25 bn 2057 paper, though there is clearly a decent concession and natural demand at the long end of the curve from the usual funds looking to weight assets vs liabilities.

Bunds: bears firmly back in control
content: Hefty corrective losses off the Eurex open as the fall-out from yesterday’s stronger than expected US inflation data continues in fixed income markets that have also lost any prop on asset-switching or safe-haven grounds given the positive tone in global equities after initial Wall Street wobbles on heightened Fed tightening probabilities. The 10 year German debt future gapped down 33 ticks from the get go and dipped further to a 157.58 low before finding what looks like fragile base and token rebound to 157.73 as US Treasuries remain under pressure and yields continue to grind higher. Heavy supply to make room for as Spain, France and the UK offer bonds ahead of the 30 year US TIPS auction, plus more US data including PPI and several CB speakers scheduled with Mersch, Praet and Lautenshlaeger representing the ECB.

content:
THIS WEEK’S EURO-AREA CASHFLOWS:

Euro-area conventional bond supply is estimated at around EUR 23bln this week; UBS estimates there will be EUR 2.15bln of cash flows (around EUR 1bln each from Germany and Portugal, with both falling in the 5-year to 7-year sectors). Next week, EUR 17.5bln of cashflows are expected.

AUCTION PREVIEW: Spanish EUR 4-5bln 0.45% 2022, 1.4% 2028 and 2.35% 2033 Bond Auction

IFR:

- There has been a modest widening of 10yr Spain(Oct 27s)/Germany is recent sessions after basing out on Feb 8.

- The key thing to look out for tomorrow is any last minute weakness in the issues for sale, that then go bid into the deadline and following the results.

- Typically Spanish auctions see the weighted average yield come through the offer side of the market at the bidding deadline, that is taken as an indication of healthy demand.

In terms of historical data:

0.45% 2022 prev. b/c 3.6 and average yield 0.324%

1.4% 2028 (no directly comparable data)

2.35% 2033 prev. b/c 1.54 and average yield 2.098%

Bids are submitted by 0930GMT and results are published shortly after.

AUCTION PREVIEW: French EUR 7-8bln 0% 2021, 0% 2023 and 6% 2025 Bond Auction

IFR:

- Good outright concession in place from prior front-end OAT auctions January 18

- Belly and especially OTR 10-year paper underperforms within French curve

- Front-end OATs attractive as part of box trades against Germany, swaps

- Chunky German, French redemptions coming

In terms of historical data:

0% 2021 prev. b/c 2.05 and average yield -0.24%

0% 2023 prev. b/c 2.14and average yield 2.68%

6% 2025 prev. b/c 2.28 and average yield 0.2%

Bids are submitted by 0950GMT and results are published shortly after.

AUCTION PREVIEW: UK DMO to tap 1.75% July-2057 for GBP 2.25bln

IFR:

The last sale of the issue on May 16 2017 was a syndicated tap of GBP 5bln and was a solid affair. They add that anything other than a strong auction will be a bit of a surprise to the market. The inherent institutional support from pension funds that longer dated sales historically attract will invariably lead to a solid cover. In addition, the 1t57 also looks attractive on a relative value basis. The issue trades inverted on the fly between the 4q55 and the 460s, and there is even better value to be garnered when looking at swap boxes versus those two issues.

UBS:

- On a modified duration weighted fly, the bond has underperformed

- The bond is slightly cheap against its average z-spread over the last 3 months

- Like to buy vs 68s to take advantage of the possibility of an extension of the curve

No recent historical data.

Bids are submitted by 1030GMT and results are published shortly after.

content:
**EUROPEAN EQUITY COVERAGE WILL ONLY COVER COMPANIES IN THE STOXX 600 OR COMPANIES OF SYSTEMIC IMPORTANCE TO PARTICULAR SECTORS**

15th February 2018

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700GMT/0100CST recapping all of the overnight equity news

From 0700GMT/0100CST all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715GMT/0115CST.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750GMT/0150CST recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715GMT/0115CST ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

Asian stocks traded higher as the region received a tailwind from US where all major indices finished with firm gains and the DJIA posted its best 4-day performance in almost a decade. ASX 200 (+1.2%) was positive with its biggest movers dictated by earnings releases and as commodity names were underpinned by strength in the complex. Elsewhere, Nikkei 225 (+1.5%) advanced and managed to overlook a firmer JPY and slump in machine orders, while Hang Seng (+1.6%) closed the session as the outperformer in a holiday-shortened session, before it joined its mainland counterparts for Lunar New Year celebrations.

FTSE

Antofagasta (ANTO LN) –Co. received environmental approval for a USD 1.1bln revamp of its Los Pelambres copper mine, as stated by the government of Coquimbo on Wednesday. (Newswires) 

AstraZeneca (AZN LN)/Hargreaves Lansdown (HL/ LN)/Royal Dutch Shell (RDSA LN)/Unilever(ULVR LN) – Will trade without entitlement to their latest dividend pay-out on Thursday, trimming 24.4 points off the FTSE100. (Newswires)

OTHER UK COMPANIES

GVC (GVC LN) / Ladbrokes (LCL LN) – GVC has given away its Turkey business, hoping the move will help the takeover of Ladbrokes, following GVC’s lenders baulked at the exposure to a country where internet betting is not legal. (Newswires)

BROKER MOVES

TULLOW OIL (TLW LN) DOWNGRADED TO EQUAL WEIGHT FROM OVERWEIGHT AT BARCLAYS

OLD MUTUAL (OML LN) UPGRADED TO BUY FROM HOLD AT RENCAP

DAX

OTHER GERMAN COMPANIES

Linde (LIN GY) - EU commission would like Linde-Praxair (PX) to divest to its competitors. (Newswires)

BROKER MOVES

THYSSENKRUPP (TKA GY) UPGRADED TO REDUCE FROM SELL AT ALPHAVALUE

CAC

ADP (ADP FP) – Co. saw 7.6mln passengers in Jan 2018, +4.5% from Jan 2017. Number of connecting passengers +4.0%. Connecting rate stood at 26%, stable compared to January 2017. (Newswires)

Schneider Electric (SU FP) – FY adj. EBITA EUR 3.65bln vs. Exp. EUR 3.66bln. FY net profit group share EUR 2.15bln vs. Exp. EUR 2.10bln. FY revenue EUR 24.74bln vs. Exp. EUR 24.75bln. Co. sees negative FX impact on FY 2018 revenues of between EUR 1bln and EUR 1.1bln. Co. sees 2018 organic adj. EBITA margin expansion towards the upper end of +20bps to +50bps range. (Newswires)

Capgemini (CAP FP) – FY operating margin EUR 1.44bln vs. Exp. EUR 1.51bln. FY revenues EUR 12.54bln vs. Exp. EUR 12.76bln. Proposed dividend + EUR 0.15 to EUR 1.70/shr. (Newswires)

Airbus (AIR FP) -  FY17 net EUR 2.87bln vs. Prev. EUR 995mln, Adj. EBIT EUR 4.3bln vs. Exp. EUR 4.0bln, rev. EUR 67.0bln vs. Exp. EUR 67.1bln. EUR 1.3bln charge in 2017 on A400M. Additionally, Alexandre de Juniac is seen as a candidate to replace CEO Tom Enders. (Newswires)

Air Liquide (AI FP) – FY 17 net profit rose 19.3% to EUR 2.2bln, revenue rose 2.9% to EUR 20.35bln, operating income rose 7.5% to EUR 3.36bln, will propose dividend of EUR 2.65/shr. (Newswires)

OTHER FRENCH COMPANIES

Ipsen (IPN FP) – Strong 2017 results with 21.1% sales growth and an increase of 3.4 pct points in core operating margin, at 26.4%. Expects significant sales and margin growth in 2018. (Newswires)

Fonciere des Regions (FDR FP) – FY 2017 revenue EUR 927mln vs. Prev. EUR 909mln and recurring net EUR 2391mln vs. Prev. EUR 355.5mln. (Newswires)

 

BROKER MOVES

ADP (ADP FP) DOWNGRADED TO REDUCE FROM HOLD AT HSBC

PAN-EUROPE

Aegon (AGN NA) – Q4 Net income EUR 986mln vs. Exp. EUR 652mln. 2017 dividend of EUR 0.14/shr. Co. stated significant increase in future recurring earnings and capita; generation from US tax reform. (Newswires)

BROKER MOVES

SMI

Nestle (NESN SW) – FY organic growth +2.4% vs. Exp. 2.7%. FY net profit CHF 7.2bln vs. Exp. CHF 9.63bln. FY sales CHF 89.8bln vs. Exp. CHF 90.1bln. Co. to propose dividend of CHF 2.35/shr vs. Exp. CHF 2.40/shr. Co. sees organic growth between 2% and 4% in 2018. Co. says 2018 reconstructing costs are expected at around CHF 700mln. Co. says board of directors have decided to explore strategic options, including a potential sale for its Gerber life insurance business. (Newswires)

BROKER MOVES

SCANDINAVIA

BROKER MOVES

US

EQUITIES: S&P +1.3% at 2699, Nasdaq100 +1.9% at 6675, DJIA +1% at 24893

Top sectors: Technology +1.57%, Consumer Cyclicals +1.30% and Energy +1.29%

Bottom sectors: Utilities -0.72%, Telecom -0.68% and Consumer Non Cyclicals -0.01%

In an immediate reaction to strong CPI data/weak retail sales data, equities skidded lower, and in pre-market action, the emini shed 40 points to 2630 on the notion that the data will give the FOMC more fuel to continue reducing its accommodation, with four hikes in 2018 now becoming a baseline view for more, and more market participants (the FOMC itself has forecast three hikes in 2018). That in itself is a problematic view, some say, arguing that the terminal rate it probably a better focal point, and nothing about today’s data suggest that there will be a higher peak of the Federal Funds Rate in this hiking cycle. As cash trade got underway, equities bounced back, with the emini eventually rising towards 2700, though seemed unable to breach that level. Many traders noted that the initial sell-off to the data was somewhat overdone given that the health of corporate America is still in good shape (corporate earnings have looked good – thus far, 72% of the 354 S&P 500 companies that had reported at the end of play yesterday had beat expectations, some desk note, while February dividend flows remain a supporting factor), while some took comfort from the Nasdaq punching above its 50dma. The equity surge came amid another fall in VIX, with the index falling to beneath 20 on Wednesday. Spooz have now printed straight four days of gains.

subject: DAILY EUROPEAN OPENING NEWS: Asian stocks traded higher as the region received a tailwind from US where all major indices finished with firm gains
content:
• Asian stocks traded higher as the region received a tailwind from US where all major indices finished with firm gains
  • The USD languished from the prior day’s losses. AUD/USD remained firmer post-jobs data
  • Looking ahead, highlights include US weekly jobs, Philly Fed, PPI, IP and a slew of speakers

ASIA

Asian stocks traded higher as the region received a tailwind from US where all major indices finished with firm gains and the DJIA posted its best 4-day performance in almost a decade. ASX 200 (+1.2%) was positive with its biggest movers dictated by earnings releases and as commodity names were underpinned by strength in the complex. Elsewhere, Nikkei 225 (+1.5%) advanced and managed to overlook a firmer JPY and slump in machine orders, while Hang Seng (+1.6%) closed the session as the outperformer in a holiday-shortened session, before it joined its mainland counterparts for Lunar New Year celebrations. Finally, 10yr JGBs were relatively flat with early mild pressure seen amid the uptick in riskier assets, although this was later counterbalanced amid the BoJ’s presence in the market for 1yr-10yr JGBs totalling over JPY 1tln.

Japanese Machinery Orders MM (Dec) -11.9% vs. Exp. -2.0% (Prev. 5.7%). (Newswires)
Japanese Machinery Orders YY (Dec) -5.0% vs. Exp. 1.8% (Prev. 4.1%)


UK/EU

UK PM May is reportedly facing a crisis related to the Brexit border deal, after Northern Ireland power sharing discussions were said to have collapsed. (Telegraph)

The EU will demand the right to raid financial services firms in Britain after Brexit and hand its regulators sweeping new powers, as Brussels moves to shackle the City of London with red tape after the UK leaves the bloc. (Telegraph)

EU diplomats have removed a so-called "punishment clause" from a draft text of the arrangement for the Brexit transition period, the BBC understands. (BBC)
 

FX

The USD languished from the prior day’s losses in which firmer than expected CPI data and subsequent increased calls for more hikes from the Fed, failed to plug the greenback’s 2018 losses. This was attributed to various factors including stagflation and deficit concerns, while some also suggested the data wasn’t likely to result to a higher peak of the Federal Funds Rate in the current hiking cycle. AUD/USD remained firmer despite a bout of indecision following Employment Change data which beat expectations but was solely driven by part-timers, as Full-Time Employment contracted substantially. Elsewhere, JPY continued to strengthen with USD/JPY firmly below 107.00 as Japanese officials remained coy to the recent price action and Finance Minister Aso stated the JPY strength was not enough to require intervention.

Australian Employment Change (Jan) 16.0k vs. Exp. 15.0k (Prev. 34.7k, Rev. 33.5k). (Newswires)
Australian Unemployment Rate (Jan) 5.5% vs. Exp. 5.5% (Prev. 5.5%, Rev. 5.6%)
Australian Full Time Employment Change (Jan) -49.8k (Prev. 15.1k, Rev. 12.7k)
Australian Part-Time Employment Change (Jan) 65.9k (Prev. 19.5k)

South Africa President Zuma announced to resign with immediate effect and stated he was compelled to resign by his party. (Newswires)

COMMODITIES

Commodities extended on the prior day’s gains with a weaker USD the main driving force behind the uplift in the complex. This saw WTI crude futures reclaim the USD 61/bbl level as yesterday’s comments from Saudi Energy Minister Al-Falih continued to resonate, while gold and copper also benefitted overnight amid the greenback’s woes. 

US President Trump is said to support a USD 0.25 gas tax hike. (Axios)

GEOPOLITICAL

US Vice President Pence stated the US is open to conversation with North Korea but noted sanctions will not be removed until the regimes nuclear programme is cancelled, while he also stated that the US has viable military options to deal with the situations but hopes to solve it with peaceful means. (Newswires)

US

Treasury yields were higher across the curve after solid CPI data raised the prospects of further Fed hikes in 2018. Once again, most of the action was in the belly, with 10-year yields rising to four-year highs above 2.90% (+7bps at settlement). Longer-end yields didn’t rise as aggressively, with 30s up by 5bps at settlement, outperforming the short-end, where yields on 2s were +7bps and 5s were +9bps.  The probability of a March hike rose above 80%, according to money market pricing; the probability of three 2018 rate rises rose to 64% from 50% at the close of play on Tuesday, while the chances of four hikes jumped to 26% from 17% yesterday. Tomorrow, the US Treasury will auction USD 7bln in 30-year TIPS. US 10yr T-Notes settle down 21+ ticks at 120-10+.

DACA deal was said to be reached by a bipartisan senate group, according to reports. (Newswires)

content:
Asia stocks trade higher across the board as region gets a tailwind from US where all major indices finished with firm gains and the DJIA posted its best 4-day performance in almost a decade. ASX 200 (+0.9%) is positive with its biggest movers dictated by earnings releases and with commodity names underpinned by strength in the complex. Elsewhere, Nikkei 225 (+0.9%) advanced and managed to overlook a firmer JPY and slump in machine orders, while Hang Seng (+1.3%) also edges gains in a holiday-shortened session, before joining its mainland counterparts for Lunar New Year celebrations.

In FX markets, the USD languishes from the prior day’s losses where firmer than expected CPI data and subsequent increased calls for more hikes from the Fed, failed to plug the greenback’s 2018 losses. This was attributed to various factors including stagflation and deficit concerns, while some also suggested the data isn’t likely to result to a higher peak of the Federal Funds Rate in the current hiking cycle. AUD/USD remains firmer despite a bout of indecision following Employment Change data which beat expectations but was solely driven by part-timers as Full-Time Employment contracted substantially. Elsewhere, JPY continued to strengthen with USD/JPY firmly below 107.00 as Japanese officials remain coy to the recent price action with Finance Minister Aso stating the JPY strength is not enough to require intervention.

Finally, 10yr JGBs are relatively flat with mild pressure seen amid the uptick in riskier assets, while the BoJ’s Rinban announcement for 1yr-10yr JGBs failed to impact prices as the central kept the amounts unchanged from prior.
